cards.front:
Evaluation of the interior of a crashed motor vehicle during extrication will allow the EMT to:

A. determine the vehicleâ€™s speed at the time of impact.
B. assess the severity of the third collision of the crash.
C. identify contact points and predict potential injuries.
D. recognize if the driver hit the brakes before impact.
See Blunt Trauma
cards.back: identify contact points and predict potential injuries.

cards.front:
In contrast to a Level III trauma center, a Level I trauma center must:

A. be involved in trauma prevention programs.
B. have general surgeons in-house 24 hours a day.
C. be able to stabilize patients before transferring to a higher level facility.
D. have access to an emergency physician within 30 minutes.
See Management: Transport and Destinations
cards.back: have general surgeons in-house 24 hours a day.

cards.front:
Signs of a pulmonary blast injury include:

A. multiple rib fractures.
B. coughing up blood.
C. vomiting blood.
D. an irregular pulse.
See Blast Injuries
cards.back: coughing up blood.

cards.front:
When assessing an elderly patient who fell, it is important to remember that:

A. bilateral hip fractures usually occur when an elderly person falls.
B. any fall in the elderly is considered to be high-energy trauma.
C. osteoporosis can cause a fracture as a result of a fall from a standing position.
D. elderly patients who fall usually have a secondary head injury.
See Blunt Trauma
cards.back: osteoporosis can cause a fracture as a result of a fall from a standing position.

cards.front:
Airbags are designed to:

A. be used with or without a shoulder harness.
B. prevent a second collision inside the car.
C. prevent the driver from sustaining head trauma.
D. decrease the severity of deceleration injuries.
See Blunt Trauma
cards.back: decrease the severity of deceleration injuries.

cards.front:
If one or more occupants in the same vehicle are killed in a crash, the EMT should:

A. transport the survivors only if they have injuries or complain of pain.
B. rapidly assess only the survivors who have experienced obvious trauma.
C. allow the survivors to refuse transport if they have no obvious injuries.
D. suspect that all living occupants experienced the same serious trauma.
See Blunt Trauma
cards.back: suspect that all living occupants experienced the same serious trauma.

cards.front:
Which of the following interventions is the MOST critical to the outcome of a patient with multisystem trauma?

A. Elevation of the lower extremities
B. Early administration of oxygen
C. Intravenous fluid administration
D. Rapid transport to a trauma center
See Multisystem Trauma
cards.back: Rapid transport to a trauma center

cards.front:
The index of suspicion is MOST accurately defined as:

A. the way in which traumatic injuries occur.
B. the detection of less obvious life-threatening injuries.
C. a predictable pattern that leads to serious injuries.
D. your awareness and concern for potentially serious underlying injuries.
See Introduction
cards.back: your awareness and concern for potentially serious underlying injuries.

cards.front:
Which of the following findings would be LEAST suggestive of the presence of high-energy trauma?

A. Dismounted seats
B. Deployment of the airbag
C. Intrusion into the vehicle
D. Steering wheel collapse
See Blunt Trauma
cards.back: Deployment of the airbag

cards.front:
Internal injuries caused by gunshot wounds are difficult to predict because:

A. exit wounds caused by the bullet are usually small.
B. the bullet may tumble or ricochet within the body.
C. the area of damage is usually smaller than the bullet.
D. the caliber of the bullet is frequently unknown.
See Penetrating Trauma
cards.back: the bullet may tumble or ricochet within the body.

cards.front:
When assessing the interior of a crashed motor vehicle for damage, you are gathering information regarding the:

A. index of suspicion.
B. potential energy.
C. kinetic energy.
D. mechanism of injury.
See Energy and Trauma
cards.back: mechanism of injury.

cards.front:
Which of the following would MOST likely occur as the direct result of the second collision in a motor vehicle crash?

A. Collapsed dashboard
B. Intrathoracic hemorrhage
C. Deformed steering wheel
D. Caved-in passenger door
See Blunt Trauma
cards.back: Deformed steering wheel

cards.front:
According to the American College of Surgeons Committee on Trauma (ACS-COT), an adult trauma patient should be transported to the highest level of trauma center if he or she:

A. has a bleeding disorder or takes anticoagulant medications and has any blunt or penetrating injury.
B. has a systolic blood pressure of less than 110 mm Hg or a heart rate greater than 110 beats/min.
C. was involved in a motor vehicle crash in which another patient in the same vehicle was killed.
D. has a GCS score of less than or equal to 13 with a mechanism attributed to trauma.
See Management: Transport and Destinations
cards.back: has a GCS score of less than or equal to 13 with a mechanism attributed to trauma.

cards.front:
Force acting over a distance is the definition of:

A. potential energy.
B. work.
C. kinetic energy.
D. latent energy.
See Energy and Trauma
cards.back: work.

cards.front:
The phenomenon of pressure waves emanating from the bullet, causing damage remote from its path, is known as:

A. cavitation.
B. conversion.
C. capitation.
D. congruent.
See Penetrating Trauma
cards.back: cavitation.

cards.front:
A driver involved in a rollover motor vehicle crash will MOST likely experience serious injuries or death if he or she:

A. remains within the vehicle.
B. experiences multiple impacts.
C. is wearing only a lap belt.
D. is ejected or partially ejected.
See Blunt Trauma
cards.back: is ejected or partially ejected.

cards.front:
Factors that should be considered when assessing a patient who has fallen include all of the following, EXCEPT:

A. the height of the fall.
B. the primary impact point.
C. the speed of the fall.
D. the surface struck.
See Blunt Trauma
cards.back: the speed of the fall.

cards.front:
The energy of a moving object is called:

A. potential energy.
B. kinetic energy.
C. latent energy.
D. converted energy.
See Energy and Trauma
cards.back: kinetic energy.

cards.front:
When treating a patient who experienced a pulmonary blast injury, you should:

A. use a demand valve to ventilate the patient.
B. suspect an accompanying cardiac tamponade.
C. avoid giving oxygen under positive pressure.
D. administer large amounts of intravenous fluid.
See Blast Injuries
cards.back: avoid giving oxygen under positive pressure.

cards.front:
When the speed of a motor vehicle doubles, the amount of kinetic energy:

A. doubles.
B. triples.
C. is not affected.
D. quadruples.
See Energy and Trauma
cards.back: quadruples.
